 Keep in mind that this is just conjecture becuase we are basically moving forward without precedent. No economy this large has ever had fundamentals that were this poor. The status of our currency as a reserve currency, and the fact that oil is traded in dollar, has allowed us to do some pretty stupid things and put the consequences off. In economics it is safe to say that all things eventually return to fundamentals. You can put as much lipstick as you want on a pig, but it is still a pig.
 
 What it boils down to is that this is BAD, VERY, VERY BAD for the middle and lower classes. 
 
 Who will be hit hardest depends on criteria. The poor will end up with less...a lot less....but the middle class will loose the most. Already the middle class is shrinking at an incredible rate. In fact, the middle class has been shrinking so fast that they have changed the definition of "middle class". Now if you live above the poverty level, you are middle class. they have also started including things like "imputed rent" in income calculations.
 
 The middle class has become reliant on debt to stay middle class, and that is starting to have some serious ramifications. As much as I dislike hillary Clinton, her claim that we have a "trap door" economy in the US is dead on. More and more people are going to start falling through the trap door. 
 
 For the middle class, the future holds increased unemployment, decreased purchasing power, probably lower wages (depending on how high inflation runs), and for many, reduction to poverty. 
 
 In your case, assuming you did not leave out some important information like "And $75,000 in credit card debt", you may be in pretty good shape, or really bad shape, depending on exactly what your job is, who you work for, and how critical your position is.
 
 The financial sector has shed over 150,000 jobs this year and that is expected to continue. Recently several investment banks put up $100 billion to create a fund with the sole intention of putting a floor under traded securities. It is being billed as a "subprime superfund". What does that mean, though?
 
 That means that things are so bad that Americas leading banks have put up a huge amount of capital in order to fund the biggest price fixing scheme in the history of the planet earth. Not only that, things are so bad that the SEC and the treasury department have not only failed to prohibit this massive price fixing scheme, they have helped orchestrate it. The sad thing is that there is no possible way that this can solve the problem.
 
 In your situation, depending on how secure your job is, you probably want to make sure you have some money in the bank...at least enough to get by for a couple of months if you have to find a new job (assuming there are new jobs out there to find).
 
 The sad thing about this mess is that there really is nothing the middle or lower class can to do protect themselves. This correction is going to take most of them by surprise, cut them incredibly deeply, and there is nothing they can do to stop it. Just try to keep some money in the bank. That really is about all you can do.
 
 Things will basically continue to get worse until we return to fundamentals....until we are once again competitive in the world market. The problem there is that we have worked for years to keep wages in other countries low, sold off most of our industrial infrastructure, and basically put ourselves in a situation where in order to compete with china, or india, or Brazil, we have to pay our people like they are chinese, or indian, or brazillian. We import the majority of our manufactured raw materials, so a lower dollar does not help us when it comes to exports. The only thing we have to level the playing field is wages. 
 
 This may all be academic because it is possible, and maybe even likely, that we have put ourselves in a situation where we cannot survive as a nation. We have actually been so stupid that we have put ourselves in a position where our government simply cannot function without a massive influx of borrowed money each month, and it would appear that the well there is about dry. 
 
 I am assuming that last months TICs numbers will improve. If they don't our government will be insolvent by May. If we assume that Lasts month numbers are more indicitive of the pattern we can expect, then we have until august before we reach the point that the government can no longer pay its employees, honor social commitments (like food stamps, SS payments, etc...) or pay for its goods (no more bombs for Iraq).
